https://prez.dev/description.@value: Methods used to spatially locate geological features and exploration, mining and related infrastructure sites. These can be either features directly observed in the field (e.g. site/outcrop descriptions, structural readings, etc.) or obtained from legacy and current documents/datasets (e.g. airphotos, maps, previously published reports, exploration reports, etc.). Each location method has a spatial accuracy that indicates an estimate of the approximate error in the location. Captured geographical locations for geological or mining features are expressed as a set of coordinates (latitude and longitude degrees), with or without an elevation above or below sea level.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Geographical location obtained using the 'laser imaging detection and ranging' (LiDAR) method, whereby the coordinates of a point are measured from ground control points using a laser to measure the time it takes for the reflected light to return to the receiver). Typically, a Global Navigation Satellite System receiver configured over a georeferenced control point is used to link the data in with the WGS (World Geodetic System). Horizontal and vertical accuracies vary, but can be as low as 1 cm or less.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#hist.@value: LiDAR is a ground or airborne surveying technology that uses laser pulses to create high-resolution models of ground elevation or underground workings.
